        3b
        Synthesis, Structure, and Luminescent Property of a Heterometallic Metal-Organic Framework Constructed from Rod-Shaped Secondary Building Blocks
        He, Jianghua; Yu, Jihong; Zhang, Yuetao; Pan, Qinhe; Xu, Ruren
        Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (25), 9279-9282CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A new heterometallic MOF compd., [ZnNa(m-BDC)2]·NH2Me2 (MOF-CJ2; m-BDC = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate), was solvothermally synthesized and characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction, x-ray powder diffraction, ICP, TGA, IR, and photoluminescence spectroscopy analyses. It crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c with a 13.277(6), b 14.323(7), c 11.328(6) Å, and β 111.73(2)°. Its framework is constructed from M-O-C (M = Na and Zn) rods composed of alternating six-coordinated Na(I) centers and four-coordinated Zn(II) centers. These rods are linked by m-BDC links to form primitive cubic (pcu) type rod packing. This framework exemplifies the 1st open-framework heterometallic MOF structure based on the assembly of infinite rod building units.

        Structures, photoluminescence, up-conversion, and magnetism of two- and three-dimensional rare-Earth coordination polymers with multicarboxylate linkages
        Yang, Jin; Yue, Qi; Li, Guo-Dong; Cao, Jun-Jun; Li, Guang-Hua; Chen, Jie-Sheng
        Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (7), 2857-2865CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Four new rare-earth compds., [Eu(NDC)1.5(DMF)2] (1), [Nd2(NDC)3(DMF)4]·H2O (2), [La2(NDC)3(DMF)4]·0.5H2O (3), and [Eu(BTC)(H2O)] (4), where NDC = 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate, BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, were synthesized through preheating and cooling-down crystn. Compds. 1-3 possess similar two-dimensional structures in which the NDC ligands link MIII (M = La, Nd, and Eu) ions of two adjacent double chains constructed by NDC ligands and dinuclear MIII building units. In compd. 4, the EuIII ion is seven-coordinated by O atoms from six BTC ligands and one terminal H2O mol. in a distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal coordination environment. If the BTC ligand and the EuIII ion are regarded as six-connected nodes, resp., the structure of compd. 4 can be well described as a three-dimensional six-connected net. Also, compds. 1 and 4 exhibit strong red luminescence upon 355-nm excitation. Compd. 2 displays interesting emissions in the near-IR region, and yellow (580 nm) pumping of this compd. results in UV and intense blue emissions through an up-conversion process. The magnetic properties of compds. 1, 2, and 4 were studied through measurement of their magnetic susceptibilities at 4-300 K.

        4a
        Hydrogen Storage in Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Rosi, Nathaniel L.; Eckert, Juergen; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Vodak, David T.; Kim, Jaheon; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2003), 300 (5622), 1127-1130CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Metal-org. framework-5 (MOF-5) Zn4O(BDC)3 (BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) with a cubic three-dimensional extended porous structure adsorbed hydrogen up to 4.5 wt.% (17.2 hydrogen mols. per formula unit) at 78 K and 1.0 wt.% at room temp. and pressure of 20 bar. Inelastic neutron scattering spectroscopy of the rotational transitions of the adsorbed hydrogen mols. indicates two well-defined binding sites (termed I and II), which the authors assoc. with hydrogen binding to zinc and the BDC linker, resp. Preliminary studies on topol. similar isoreticular metal-org. framework-6 and -8 (IRMOF-6 and -8) having cyclobutylbenzene and naphthalene linkers, resp., gave approx. double and quadruple (2.0 wt.%) the uptake found for MOF-5 at room temp. and 10 bar.

        4b
        High H2 adsorption in a microporous metal-organic framework with open metal sites
        Chen, Banglin; Ockwig, Nathan W.; Millward, Andrew R.; Contreras, Damacio S.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2005), 44 (30), 4745-4749CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A copper-based metal-org. framework (MOF) has been synthesized, and its structure has been solved by X-ray crystallog. The remarkably high hydrogen adsorption properties (2.47 wt%) of this compd. have been studied.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXnvVSqsLY%253D&md5=ba35d52735de6fd6c9b3b4ff7f354879
        (c) Chun, H.; Dybtsev, D. N.; Kim, H.; Kim, K. Chem.—Eur. J. 2005, 11, 3521

        4c
        Synthesis, X-ray crystal structures, and gas sorption properties of pillared square grid nets based on paddle-wheel motifs: Implications for hydrogen storage in porous materials
        Chun, Hyungphil; Dybtsev, Danil N.; Kim, Hyunuk; Kim, Kimoon
        Chemistry--A European Journal (2005), 11 (12), 3521-3529CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A systematic modulation of org. ligands connecting dinuclear paddle-wheel motifs leads to isomorphous metal-org. porous materials that have a three-dimensional connectivity and interconnected pores. Arom. dicarboxylates such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (1,4-bdc), tetramethylterephthalate (tmbdc), 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate (1,4-ndc), tetrafluoroterephthalate (tfbdc), or 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate (2,6-ndc) are linear linkers that form two-dimensional layers, and diamine ligands, 4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (dabco) or 4,4'-dipyridyl (bpy), coordinate at both sides of Zn2 paddle-wheel units to bridge the layers vertically. The resulting open frameworks [Zn2(1,4-bdc)2(dabco)] (1), [Zn2(1,4-bdc)(tmbdc)(dabco)] (2), [Zn2(tmbdc)2(dabco)] (3), [Zn2(1,4-ndc)2(dabco)] (4), [Zn2(tfbdc)2(dabco)] (5), and [Zn2(tmbdc)2(bpy)] (8) possess varying size of pores and free apertures originating from the side groups of the 1,4-bdc derivs. [Zn2(1,4-bdc)2(bpy)] (6) and [Zn2(2,6-ndc)2(bpy)] (7) have two- and 3-fold interpenetrating structures, resp. The noninterpenetrating frameworks (1-5 and 8) possess surface areas at 1450-2090 m2g-1 and H sorption capacities of 1.7-2.1% at 78 K and 1 atm. A detailed anal. of the sorption data in conjunction with structural similarities and differences concludes that porous materials with straight channels and large openings do not perform better than those with wavy channels and small openings in terms of H storage through physisorption.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXlt1ygt70%253D&md5=6b32569fb5a054ae4872481379e3463c
        (d) Fletcher, A. J.; Thomas, K. M.; Rosseinsky, M. J. J. Solid State Chem. 2005, 178, 2491
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4d
        Flexibility in metal-organic framework materials: impact on sorption properties
        Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.
        Journal of Solid State Chemistry (2005), 178 (8), 2491-2510CODEN: JSSCBI; ISSN:0022-4596. (Elsevier)
        A review. Recent years have seen the development of a new class of porous coordination polymers known collectively as metal org. framework materials (MOFs). This review outlines recent progress in understanding how adsorption characteristics of these systems differ from rigid classical sorbents such as activated carbon and zeolites. Gas/vapor adsorption studies for characterization of the porous structures of MOF materials are reviewed and differences in adsorption characteristics based on detailed measurement of equil. and dynamical sorption behavior, compared with previous generations of sorbents, are highlighted. The role of framework flexibility and specific structural features, such as windows and pore cavities, within the MOF porous structures are discussed in relation to adsorption mechanisms.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXot1CgtbY%253D&md5=349cfccbf029fb292e6be84f9c730a04
        (e) Rowsell, J. L. C.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2006, 128, 1304
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4e
        Effects of Functionalization, Catenation, and Variation of the Metal Oxide and Organic Linking Units on the Low-Pressure Hydrogen Adsorption Properties of Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (4), 1304-1315CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The dihydrogen adsorption isotherms of eight metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), measured at 77 K up to a pressure of 1 atm, were examd. for correlations with their structural features. All materials display approx. Type I isotherms with no hysteresis, and satn. was not reached for any of the materials under these conditions. Among the six iso-reticular MOFs (IRMOFs) studied, the catenated materials exhibit the largest capacities on a molar basis, up to 9.8 H2 per formula unit. The addn. of functional groups (-Br, -NH2, -C2H4-) to the phenylene links of IRMOF-1 (MOF-5), or their replacement with thieno[3,2-b]thiophene moieties in IRMOF-20, altered the adsorption behavior by a minor amt. despite large variations in the pore vols. of the resulting materials. But replacement of the metal oxide units with those contg. coordinatively unsatd. metal sites resulted in greater H2 uptake. The enhanced affinities of these materials, MOF-74 and HKUST-1, were further demonstrated by calcn. of the isosteric heats of adsorption, which were larger across much of the range of coverage examd., compared to those of representative IRMOFs. Probably under low-loading conditions, the H2 adsorption behavior of MOFs can be improved by imparting larger charge gradients on the metal oxide units and adjusting the link metrics to constrict the pore dimensions; however, a large pore vol. is still a prerequisite feature.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XitV2msg%253D%253D&md5=76a0797beec956e59ca2ddf029f5a386
      5. 5
        (a) Eddaoudi, M.; Moler, D. B.; Li, H.; Chen, B.; Reineke, T.; O’Keefe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Acc. Chem. Res. 2001, 34, 319
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5a
        Modular Chemistry: Secondary Building Units as a Basis for the Design of Highly Porous and Robust Metal-Organic Carboxylate Frameworks
        Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Moler, David B.; Li, Hailian; Chen, Banglin; Reineke, Theresa M.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2001), 34 (4), 319-330CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review, with 38 refs. Secondary building units (SBUs) are mol. complexes and cluster entities in which ligand coordination modes and metal coordination environments can be used in the transformation of these fragments into extended porous networks using polytopic linkers (1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5,7-adamantanetetracarboxylate, etc.). Consideration of the geometric and chem. attributes of the SBUs and linkers leads to prediction of the framework topol., and in turn to the design and synthesis of a new class of porous materials with robust structures and high porosity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXhtFymsL0%253D&md5=e3df2f7492090aee280676f044e3b7af
        (b) Yaghi, O. M.; O’Keeffe, M.; Ockwig, N. W.; Chae, H. K.; Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J. Nature 2003, 423, 705
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5b
        Reticular synthesis and the design of new materials
        Yaghi, Omar M.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Ockwig, Nathan W.; Chae, Hee K.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2003), 423 (6941), 705-714CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. The long-standing challenge of designing and constructing new cryst. solid-state materials from mol. building blocks is just beginning to be addressed with success. A conceptual approach that requires the use of secondary building units to direct the assembly of ordered frameworks epitomizes this process: the authors call this approach reticular synthesis. This chem. has yielded materials designed to have predetd. structures, compns. and properties. In particular, highly porous frameworks held together by strong metal-O-C bonds and with exceptionally large surface area and capacity for gas storage were prepd. and their pore metrics systematically varied and functionalized.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXksV2itro%253D&md5=2417c5adb0e948350d3d62350c8cd7ea
        (c) Kitagawa, S.; Kitaura, R.; Noro, S. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2004, 43, 2334
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5c
        Functional porous coordination polymers
        Kitagawa, Susumu; Kitaura, Ryo; Noro, Shin-ichiro
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (18), 2334-2375CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Discussion concs. on three aspects of coordination polymers: (1) the use of crystal engineering to construct porous frameworks from connectors and linkers (nano-space engineering), (2) characterizing and cataloging the porous properties by functions for storage, exchange, sepn., etc., and (3) the next generation of porous functions based on dynamic crystal transformations caused by guest mols. or phys. stimuli. The authors' aim is to present the state of the art chem. and physics of and in the micropores of porous coordination polymers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXktFShtLk%253D&md5=9df52e99bad3cc0db67f65551a8c154f
      6. 6
        (a) Batten, S. R.; Robson, R. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 1998, 37, 1461
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6a
        Interpenetrating nets: ordered, periodic entanglement
        Batten, Stuart R.; Robson, Richard
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (1998), 37 (11), 1461-1494CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        A review, with many refs. Taking inspiration from the examples biol. provides for the organization of simple units into a vast range of intricate and beautiful structures with complex and wonderfully efficient functions, many chemists were turning their attention to the deliberate design of self-assembling aggregates of mol. building blocks with some specific structural or functional purpose in mind. This is supramol. chem. It embraces systems ranging upwards in size and complexity to include infinite solid arrays. Mol. entanglement is common in biol. Entanglement that is inextricable, in the sense that disentanglement can be achieved only by breaking internal connections, was one of the major themes of supramol. chem. Such inextricable entanglements-as seen in catenanes, rotaxanes, and mol. knots-have provided a longstanding fascination for chemists, and many beautiful examples of ingenious design were constructed. In the area of solids, the deliberate control of structure, and therefore properties and function, is a long-term objective being vigorously pursued by numerous groups. Increasingly, solid structures are being invented and created rather than discovered. The potential for technol. useful electronic, optical, electrochem., and catalytic applications is an obvious driving force for much of this work, but the area is also of great fundamental structural interest and importance. Framework solids, which are often accessible by self-assembly under exceedingly mild conditions, are particularly attractive in this context because of their chem. and structural diversity and aesthetic appeal and because of the control potentially achievable in their construction. One aspect of framework solids which becomes increasingly apparent as more of them are discovered or invented is their tendency to form entangled structures in which two or more independent infinite networks interpenetrate each other. Polycatenane or polyrotaxane assocns. are an inherent feature of these structures. Examples of interpenetration were relatively rare until recently, but they are now being reported with increasing frequency. This is an opportune time to review this expanding area.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXkt12gsr8%253D&md5=5742130bfdbcd77c480e2bcb42c3e46c
        (b) Moulton, B.; Zaworotko, M. J. Chem. Rev. 2001, 101, 1629
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6b
        From molecules to crystal engineering. Supramolecular isomerism and polymorphism in network solids
        Moulton, Brian; Zaworotko, Michael J.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, D. C.) (2001), 101 (6), 1629-1658CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review with 299 refs. on how the advances in supramol. chem. have impacted the manner in which chemists view the existence of single crystals and the design of new cryst. phases. Coordination polymers, H-bonded networks, and supramol. isomerism and polymorphism are considered.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXjtlyqtrg%253D&md5=00fbfe863055d07d1773be77dc52f023
        (c) Rao, C. N. R.; Natarajan, S.; Vaidhyanathan, R. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2004, 43, 1466
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6c
        Metal carboxylates with open architectures
        Rao, C. N. R.; Natarajan, Srinivasan; Vaidhyanathan, R.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (12), 1466-1496CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. The field of inorg. open-framework materials is dominated by aluminosilicates and phosphates. The metal carboxylates have emerged as an important family in the last few years. This family includes not only mono- and dicarboxylates of transition, rare-earth, and main-group metals, but also a variety of hybrid structures. Some of the carboxylates possess novel adsorption and magnetic properties. Dicarboxylates and related species provide an effective means of designing novel hybrid structures with porous and other properties. In some of these structures, the dicarboxylate acts as a linker between two inorg. units. Hybrid nanocomposites are also of particular note, for example, cadmium oxalate host lattices that can accommodate extended alkali-metal halide structures. This review discusses the synthesis, structure, and properties of various types of open-framework metal carboxylates.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXisl2hsbo%253D&md5=32807fb667da7932d3bd2ace7e18f208
        (d) Wang, X. L.; Qin, C.; Wang, E. B.; Xu, L.; Su, Z. M.; Hu, C. W. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2004, 43, 5036
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6d
        Interlocked and interdigitated architectures from self-assembly of long flexible ligands and cadmium salts
        Wang, Xin-Long; Qin, Chao; Wang, En-Bo; Xu, Lin; Su, Zhong-Min; Hu, Chang-Wen
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (38), 5036-5040CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Noninterpenetrating structures are formed by self-assembly of Cd salts and long flexible ligands, namely [Cd(bpea)(phen)2] (I) (H2bpea = biphenylethene-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid), [Cd2(bpea)(pt)(phen)2][Cd(pt)(phen)].2H2O (II) (H2pt = phthalic acid) and [Cd3(bpea)(phen)3(OH)3(H2O)].0.5bpea.4H2O (III). For I exceptional 9-fold interlocked homochiral helixes are built from achiral components. The helixes are chem. independent but phys. interwoven. This represents the highest degree of entanglement presently known for a noninterpenetrating system. The crystal structures of I, II and III were detd. The photoluminescence of III was studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXotlKrsbs%253D&md5=3b13359a617d53303a67335f89fe8803
        (e) Eddaoudi, M.; Moler, D. B.; Li, H.; Chen, B.; Reineke, T. M.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Acc. Chem. Res. 2001, 34, 319

        A review, with 38 refs. Secondary building units (SBUs) are mol. complexes and cluster entities in which ligand coordination modes and metal coordination environments can be used in the transformation of these fragments into extended porous networks using polytopic linkers (1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5,7-adamantanetetracarboxylate, etc.). Consideration of the geometric and chem. attributes of the SBUs and linkers leads to prediction of the framework topol., and in turn to the design and synthesis of a new class of porous materials with robust structures and high porosity.

        (f) James, S. L. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2003, 32, 276
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6f
        Metal-organic frameworks
        James, Stuart L.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2003), 32 (5), 276-288CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Metal-org. frameworks are a recently-identified class of porous polymeric material, consisting of metal ions linked together by org. bridging ligands, and are a new development on the interface between mol. coordination chem. and materials science. A range of novel structures was prepd. which feature amongst the largest pores known for cryst. compds., very high sorption capacities and complex sorption behavior not seen in aluminosilicate zeolites. The development of synthetic approaches to these materials and studies of their properties are reviewed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        (a) Potts, K. T. Chem. Rev. 1961, 61, 87

        7a
        The chemistry of 1,2,4-triazoles
        Potts, K. T.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (1961), 61 (), 87-127CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665.
        A review with 377 references.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF3MXmsFShtg%253D%253D&md5=86a28cd3b6652ad357c7a3fb8f057c7d
        (b) Haasnoot, J. G. Coord. Chem. Rev. 2000, 200–202, 131
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7b
        Mononuclear, oligonuclear and polynuclear metal coordination compounds with 1,2,4-triazole derivatives as ligands
        Haasnoot, J. G.
        Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2000), 200-202 (), 131-185CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier Science S.A.)
        A review with 275 refs. on transition metal complexes of 1,2,4-Triazole and its derivs. details their ability to unite the coordination geometry of both pyrazoles and imidazoles, and in addn. exhibit a strong and typical property of acting as bridging ligands between two metal centers. In this bridging capacity, the 1,2,4-triazole ligands show a great coordination diversity, esp. when the triazole nucleus is substituted with addnl. donor groups. This property together with their strong σ donor properties and the relative ease of synthesis make them very appealing for the design of new polynuclear metal complexes with interesting properties. A no. of x-ray structures were evaluated in some detail.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXmtVCms7k%253D&md5=d1bf3640173902c5f0ebb5b0c16c9237
        (c) Klingele, M. H.; Brooker, S. Coord. Chem. Rev. 2003, 241, 119
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7c
        The coordination chemistry of 4-substituted 3,5-di(2-pyridyl)-4H-1,2,4-triazoles and related ligands
        Klingele, Marco H.; Brooker, Sally
        Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2003), 241 (1-2), 119-132CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        A review is presented on the coordination chem. of 4-substituted 3,5-di(2-pyridyl)-4H-1,2,4-triazoles, and of the related ligands 2,5-di(2-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole and 2,5-di(2-pyridyl)-1,3,4-thiadiazole. Literature surveys of the known 4-substituted 3,5-di(2-pyridyl)-4H-1,2,4-triazoles and their complexes are provided, selected representative examples are presented and the various coordination modes that were obsd. in complexes of these potentially dinucleating ligands are discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXksVGku7s%253D&md5=26a162c91c5a077e9b261844334adfdb

        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (e) Ferrer, S.; Haasnoot, J. G.; Reedijk, J.; Müller, E.; Cingi, M. B.; Lanfranchi, M. A.; Lanfredi, M. M.; Ribas, J. Inorg. Chem. 2000, 39, 1859
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7e
        Trinuclear N,N-Bridged Copper(II) Complexes Involving a Cu3OH Core: [Cu3(μ3-OH)L3A(H2O)2]A·(H2O)x {L = 3-Acetylamino-1,2,4-triazolate; A = CF3SO3, NO3, ClO4; x = 0, 2}. Synthesis, X-ray Structures, Spectroscopy, and Magnetic Properties
        Ferrer, Sacramento; Haasnoot, Jaap G.; Reedijk, Jan; Mueller, Edgar; Biagini Cingi, Marina; Manotti Lanfranchi, Maurizio; Lanfredi, Anna Maria; Ribas, Joan
        Inorganic Chemistry (2000), 39 (9), 1859-1867CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The reaction of Haat [Haat = (3-acetylamino-1,2,4-triazole)] with aquated Cu(CF3SO3)2, Cu(NO3)2, and Cu(ClO4)2, resp., in water results in trinuclear [Cu3(OH)(aat)3(CF3SO3)(H2O)2](CF3SO3) (1), [Cu3(OH)(aat)3(NO3)(H2O)2](NO3)(H2O)2 (2), and [Cu3(OH)(aat)3(ClO4)(H2O)2](ClO4) (3). The synthesis, x-ray structure, and magnetic and spectroscopic properties of the three title complexes are described. The cation of the three complexes is trinuclear with a Cu3OH skeleton which has the N-N diazine grouping of a triazole ring as bridge between each pair of copper atoms. The Cu3OH units have an av. Cu-O distance of 1.991(6) (1), 2.000(6) (2), and 2.007(6) (3) Å, an av. Cu-Cu' distance of 3.355(2) (1), 3.341(1) (2), and 3.371(3) (3) Å, and an av. Cu-O-Cu' angle of 114.6(3)° (1), 112.4(2)° (2), and 115.4(3)° (3). The existence of the Cu3OH fragment is confirmed by a pseudotetrahedral oxygen environment, by detection of the OH hydrogen atom, and by stoichiometry. In the trinuclear unit the metal ions show, in the 1st approxn., a pseudo-square-planar pyramidal environment forming a CuN2O3 chromophore; three of the basal positions are occupied by N,N,O aat ligand atoms, the 4th one is occupied by the oxygen of the central OH group, and the apical site is occupied by an oxygen atom from a water mol. in the case of two of the copper(II) atoms and by an oxygen atom from the coordinating anion in the case of the 3rd metal ion. The three compds. exhibit strong antiferromagnetic interaction, with similar J consts. [J = -197.7 (1), J = -190.9 (2), J = -198.2 (3) cm-1], reaching complete spin coupling at ∼75 K (1)/55 K (2)/95 K (3). At very low temp. the magnetic moment (magnetic susceptibility) falls below that expected for one unpaired electron. Magnetic parameters are discussed from the structural results and compared with those reported in the literature for related trimeric Cu(II) compds. with N-O or N-N peripheral bridges. Solid state EPR spectra of the three complexes recorded at liq. N temp. show axial signals. Crystal data: C14H20Cu3F6N12O12S2 (1) (Mw = 917.16) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group, P21/c, Z = 4, with cell dimensions a 13.080(2), b 17.202(2), c 13.840(2) Å, β 92.40(1)°, dc = 1.958 Mg m-3; the final agreement values were space group R1 = 0.0582 and wR2 = 0.1462 for 7107 unique reflections. C12H24Cu3N14O14 (2) (Mw = 779.07) crystallizes in the triclinic space group, P‾1, Z = 2, with cell dimensions a 9.647(2), b 9.985(2), c 15.314(2) Å, α 84.080(10), β 87.694(10), γ 65.030(10)°, dc = 1.945 Mg m-3; the final agreement values were R1 = 0.0397 and wR2 = 0.0950 for 7728 unique reflections. C12H20Cl2Cu3N12O14 (3) (Mw = 817.92) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group, P21/a, Z = 4, with a 14.238(5), b 16.387(6), c 11.678(4) Å, γ 90.45(2)°, dc = 1.994 Mg m-3; the final agreement values were R1 = 0.0616 and wR2 = 0.1279 for 4038 unique reflections.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXivVShu7o%253D&md5=a236076889c0312ddb493a6c7791dcb1
        (f) Ferrer, S.; Lioret, F.; Bertomeu, I.; Aizuet, G.; Borrás, J.; García-Granda, S.; Liu-González, M.; Haasnoot, J. P. Inorg. Chem. 2002, 41, 5821
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7f
        Cyclic Trinuclear and Chain of Cyclic Trinuclear Copper(II) Complexes Containing a Pyramidal Cu3O(H) Core. Crystal Structures and Magnetic Properties of [Cu3(μ3-OH)(aaat)3(H2O)3](NO3)2·H2O [aaat = 3-acetylamino-5-amino-1,2,4-triazolate] and {[Cu3(μ3-OH)(aat)3(μ3-SO4)]·6H2O}n [aat = 3-acetylamino-1,2,4-triazolate]: New Cases of Spin-Frustrated Systems
        Ferrer, Sacramento; Lloret, Francesc; Bertomeu, Ignacio; Alzuet, Gloria; Borras, Joaquin; Garcia-Granda, Santiago; Liu-Gonzalez, Malva; Haasnoot, Jaap G.
        Inorganic Chemistry (2002), 41 (22), 5821-5830CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        New cyclic trinuclear Cu(II) complexes with 1,2,4-triazole ligands, [Cu3(μ3-OH)(aaat)3(H2O)3](NO3)2·H2O [Haaat = 3-acetylamino-5-amino-1,2,4-triazole] (1) and {[Cu3(μ3-OH)(aat)3(μ3-SO4)]·6H2O}n [Haat = 3-acetylamino-1,2,4-triazole] (2), were prepd. and characterized by x-ray crystallog. and magnetic measurements. Compd. 1, the first reported with the ligand (H)aaat, consists of discrete trinuclear cations, assocd. NO3- anions and lattice H2O mols. Compd. 2 consists of unusual chains of trinuclear units with a tridentate sulfato group linking the trimeric units and H2O mols. stabilizing the crystal lattice. In both complexes 1 and 2, the trinuclear [Cu3(OH)L3] unit contains a pyramidal Cu3-μ3-OH core, and an almost flat Cu3N6 ring formed by the N,N-bridging triazolato groups. The Cu...Cu' intratrimeric distances are 3.35-3.37-3.39 Å in 1 and 3.34-3.34-3.36 Å in 2. The Cu atoms are five-coordinated with a distorted square-pyramidal geometry. Magnetic measurements were performed in the 1.9-300 K temp. range. In the high-temp. region (T > 90 K), exptl. data could be satisfactorily reproduced by using an isotropic exchange model, H = -J(S1S2 + S2S3 + S1S3), with J = -194.6 cm-1 and g = 2.08 for 1, and J = -185.1 cm-1 and g = 2.10 for 2. The magnitude of the antiferromagnetic exchange in both complexes is discussed from their structural features by comparison with reported N,N-periphery-bridged trinuclear systems. To fit the exptl. magnetic data at low temp., an antisym. exchange term, HAS = G(S1xS2 + S2xS3 + S1xS3), had to be introduced, with G = 27.8(1) and 31.0(2) cm-1. Crystal data: C12H27Cu3N17O14 (1) (MW = 824.13) crystallizes in triclinic space group, P‾1, Z = 2, with a 8.852(2), b 11.491(3), c 15.404(3) Å, α 70.43(3), β 75.11(2), γ 88.43(2)°, dc = 1.922 g cm-3, with final agreement values R1 = 0.0822 and wR2 = 0.2300 for 4989 unique reflections; C12H28Cu3N12O14S (2) (MW = 787.14) crystallizes in triclinic space group, P‾1, Z = 2, with a 7.146(6), b 14.26(1), c 15.35(2) Å, α 109.0(9), β 93.6(9), γ 99.5(7)°, dc = 1.806 g cm-3, with final agreement values R1 = 0.0628 and wR2 = 0.1571 for 3997 obsd. reflections. The antisym. exchange obsd. reinforces the hypothesis that coplanarity between coordination basal planes of the interconnected Cu(II) atoms is not the decisive factor in the magnitude of the antiferromagnetic exchange within the Cu3O cluster.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xns1ykurY%253D&md5=9c4bc7f92c6ab95e0526f76f7af87b82
        (g) Liu, J. C.; Guo, G. C.; Huang, J. S.; You, X. Z. Inorg. Chem. 2003, 42, 235
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7g
        Different Oxidation States of Copper(I,I/II,II) Thiocyanate Complexes Containing 1,2,4-Triazole as a Bridging Ligand: Syntheses, Crystal Structures, and Magnetic Properties of 2-D Polymer CuI(admtrz)SCN, Linear Trinuclear [CuI2CuII(admtrz)6(SCN)2](ClO4)2, and Triangular Trinuclear [CuII3(admtrz)4(SCN)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)](ClO4)2·H2O (admtrz = 4-amino-3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazole)
        Liu, Jia-Cheng; Guo, Guo-Cong; Huang, Jin-Shun; You, Xiao-Zeng
        Inorganic Chemistry (2003), 42 (1), 235-243CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Cu thiocyanate compds. with three different oxidn. states, CuI(admtrz)SCN (1), [CuI2CuII(admtrz)6(SCN)2](ClO4)2 (2), and [CuII3(admtrz)4(SCN)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)](ClO4)2·H2O (3), were synthesized and characterized (admtrz = 4-amino-3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazole). Compds. 1 and 3 crystallize in the space group Pbca of the orthorhombic system with Z = 8, a 8.0221(2), b 32.3844(1), c 13.5659(3) Å, R1/wR2 = 0.0595/0.1674 for 1 and a 21.501(3), b 18.382(2), c 21.526(2) Å, R1/wR2 = 0.0638/0.1519 for 3. Compd. 2 crystallizes in the space group C2/c of the monoclinic system with Z = 4, a 18.772(4), b 11.739(2), c 22.838(5) Å, β 91.11(3)°, R1/wR2 = 0.0482/0.1265. The layered-type structure of 1 can be regarded as constructed from the tetranuclear Cu units double bridged by one of the two unique thiocyanate and admtrz ligands, which are bridged by the other unique thiocyanate ligands to form a two-dimensional layered structure along the a and b directions. The linear trinuclear Cu cation in mixed-valence compd. 2 consists of one two-valence Cu and two 1-valence Cu atoms which are bridged by admtrz ligands, and the external Cu(I) atoms are coordinated by terminal thiocyanate. The EPR spectra of 2 show the existence of localized mixed-valence Cu ions. The triangle trinuclear Cu cation in compd. 3 has its Cu3 triangle capped by one apical μ3-OH group, each edge bridged by a bridging admtrz ligand and each Cu atom coordinated by a N atom from the terminal thiocyanate, while one of the three edges is further bridged by another admtrz ligand and the opposite Cu1 atom is coordinated by a H2O mol. The EPR and magnetic susceptibility of compd. 3 were studied, showing antiferromagnetic behavior.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xpt1aisL8%253D&md5=a0505259f2d0a3912bce95135b3f9e61
        (h) Yi, L.; Ding, B.; Zhao, B.; Cheng, P.; Liao, D. Z.; Yan, S. P.; Jiang, Z. H. Inorg. Chem. 2004, 43, 33
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7h
        Novel Triazole-Bridged Cadmium Coordination Polymers Varying from Zero- to Three-Dimensionality
        Yi, Long; Ding, Bin; Zhao, Bin; Cheng, Peng; Liao, Dai-Zheng; Yan, Shi-Ping; Jiang, Zong-Hui
        Inorganic Chemistry (2004), 43 (1), 33-43CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Cadmium salts with different triazole ligands led to novel triazole-cadmium compds. varying from zero- to three-dimensionality. [Cd2(deatrz)2(H2O)Br4] (1) (deatrz = 3,5-diethyl-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole) is a zero-dimensional complex which uses a triazole ligand together with μ-OH2 as bridges to form a 1-dimensional chain via hydrogen-bonding contacts. {[Cd3(deatrz)2Cl6(H2O)2]·2H2O}n (2), {[Cd(dmtrz)Cl2]·1.5H2O}n (3) (dmtrz = 3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazole), and {[Cd3(deatrz)4Cl2(SCN)4]·2H2O}n (4) are polymeric 1-dimensional chains. 2 And 4 were constructed via trinuclear cadmium units bridged by triazole ligands and chloride atoms, while 3 consists of μ2-Cl, μ3-Cl, and triazole bridges, cross-linked by hydrogen bonding to give a 3-dimensional framework. {[Cd3(dmatrz)4(SCN)6]}n (5) (dmatrz = 3,5-dimethyl-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole) shows a two-dimensional structure whose fundamental units are trinuclear metal cations bridged via triazole ligands. {[Cd(dmtrz)(SCN)2]}n (6) is the first three-dimensional example in N1,N2-didentate-bridged triazole-metal compds. Six complexes exhibit six types of bridging modes of N1,N2-triazole in combination with single-atom bridges. 2, 4, And 5 are the unprecedented examples of polymeric chains and planes constructed via trinuclear metal ion clusters, whereas 3 is the first example of the μ3-Cl bridging mode in triazole-metal complexes. The authors have briefly discussed the variety of dimensionalities based on the tuning of different org. ligands and anions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXpsVKhu7s%253D&md5=7d677c9282b0ec14ab6efa3000ffa4e1
        (i) Zhou, J. H.; Cheng, U. M.; Song, Y.; Li, Y. Z.; Yu, Z.; Chen, X. T.; Xue, Z. L.; You, X. Z. Inorg. Chem. 2005, 44, 8011
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7i
        Syntheses, Structures, and Magnetic Properties of Unusual Nonlinear Polynuclear Copper(II) Complexes Containing Derivatives of 1,2,4-Triazole and Pivalate Ligands
        Zhou, Jian-Hao; Cheng, Ru-Mei; Song, You; Li, Yi-Zhi; Yu, Zhi; Chen, Xue-Tai; Xue, Zi-Ling; You, Xiao-Zeng
        Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (22), 8011-8022CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Novel polynuclear Cu(II) complexes contg. derivs. of 1,2,4-triazole and pivalate ligands, [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-adetrz)2(piv)5(H2O)]·6.5H2O (1) (adetrz = 4-amino-3,5-diethyl-1,2,4-triazole, piv = pivalate), [Cu4(μ3-OH)2(μ-atrz)2(μ-piv)4(piv)2]·2MeOH·H2O (2) (atrz = 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole), [Cu4(μ3-OH)2(μ-tbtrz)2(μ-piv)2(piv)4]·4H2O (3) (tbtrz = 4-tert-butyl-1,2,4-triazole), and [Cu4(μ3-O)2(μ-admtrz)4(admtrz)2(μ-piv)2(piv)2]·2[Cu2(μ-H2O)(μ-admtrz)(piv)4]·13H2O [4 = 4a·2(4b)·13H2O; admtrz = 4-amino-3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazole], were prepd. and structurally characterized. 1 Is an asym. triangular complex contg. a [Cu3(μ3-OH)] core with two Cu---Cu edges spanned by bridging adetrz ligands. 2, 3, And 4a are novel tetranuclear compds. contg. a [Cu4(μ3-O)2] or [Cu4(μ3-OH)2] core with Cu---Cu edges spanned by bridging 1,2,4-triazole or pivalate ligands. 4B is a dinuclear compd. with one admtrz and one H2O bridge, and it is the 1st dinuclear Cu(II) triazole complex with one bridging H2O mol. 1 Is one of few reported triangular Cu(II) complexes with derivs. of 1,2,4-triazole, while 2, 3, and 4a are the 1st group of the nonlinear tetranuclear Cu(II) compds. with derivs. of 1,2,4-triazole. Variable-temp. magnetic susceptibility studies on the powder samples of 1-3 reveal the overall antiferromagnetic coupling between CuII ions with J values of -55.6 to -12.8 cm-1 (1), -216.4 to 0 cm-1 (2), and -259.8 to 4.8 cm-1 (3).
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Crystal engineering of binary metal imidazolate and triazolate frameworks
        Zhang, Jie-Peng; Chen, Xiao-Ming
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2006), (16), 1689-1699CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. This article summarizes the recent advances in the crystal growth, structural control strategies and diverse structures of the binary metal imidazolate and triazolate frameworks, which are the simplest systems for crystal engineering of two-, three- and four-connected coordination polymers.

        8a
        Hydrothermal Synthesis and Structural Characterization of Novel Zn-Triazole-Benzenedicarboxylate Frameworks
        Park, Hyunsoo; Moureau, David M.; Parise, John B.
        Chemistry of Materials (2006), 18 (2), 525-531CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        Three new metal-org. coordination polymers were synthesized hydrothermally (or solvothermally for 3) using Zn2+ ion, 1H-1,2,4-triazole (C2H3N3), and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC, C8H6O4): Zn5(H2O)2(C2H2N3)4(C8H4O4)3·3.9H2O (1), Zn2(C2H2N3)2(C2H3N3)(C8H4O4)·2H2O (2), and Zn4(H2O)2(C2H2N3)4(C8H4O4)2·14H2O (3). Their crystal structures were detd. by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Their thermal properties were examd. by TGA. Structure 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group with a 10.192(2), b 17.764(4), c 24.437(5) Å, β 91.19(3)°. Structure 2 crystallizes in the triclinic P‾1 space group with a 7.797(2), b 10.047(2), c 13.577(3) Å, α 110.18(3), β 105.46(3), γ 93.90(3)°. Structure 3 crystallizes in monoclinic P21/n space group with a 13.475(3), b 26.949(5), c 13.509(3) Å, β 95.18(3)°. In structure 1, the units of the triazole-Zn polyhedra are linked by BDC in a zigzag fashion to create the stacking of Ph groups along the a axis. In structure 2, both triazole and BDC bridge Zn polyhedra in the (011) plane, resulting in the eight-membered channels along the a axis. In the case of structure 3, the BDC links the Zn polyhedra along the b axis to form a pillared open framework. This structure is the most porous of the compds. presented.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhtlCgsrvN&md5=3e2e981b6b2b36a379c552c98af12b50
        (b) Park, H.; Krigsfeld, G.; Parise, J. B. Cryst. Growth Des. 2007, 7, 736
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8b
        Solvothermal Synthesis and Structural Characterization of New Zn-Triazole-Sulfoisophthalate Frameworks
        Park, Hyunsoo; Krigsfeld, Gabriel; Parise, John B.
        Crystal Growth & Design (2007), 7 (4), 736-740CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Two new Zn-based coordination polymers, namely, Zn7(TRZ)8(SIP)2·7H2O (1) and Zn5Na2(DMA)4(TRZ)4(SIP)4·5H2O (2) (TRZ = 1,2,4-triazole, SIP = sulfoisophthalate, and DMA = dimethylamine), were synthesized under mild solvothermal conditions. Their crystal structures were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and their thermal properties were examd. by thermogravimetric anal. Structure 1 crystallizes in monoclinic P21/n space group (a = 14.050(3) Å, b = 12.517(3) Å, c = 15.377(3) Å, β = 97.95(3)°, V = 2678.3(9) Å3, Z = 2), while structure 2 is described as triclinic P‾1 (a = 9.701(2) Å, b = 12.442(3) Å, c = 17.218(3) Å, α = 89.83(3)°, β = 75.01(3)°, γ = 73.33(3)°, V = 1917.5(7) Å3, Z = 1). Structure 1 contains 8- and 16-membered channels made of Zn polyhedra linked by TRZ which are occupied by water mols. and SIP ligands. Structure 2 consists of one-dimensional chains of Zn-TRZ moieties that are linked to each other via SIP. It is a neg. charged open framework in which Na+ ions and protonated dimethylamine in the cavities serve as counterions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXisVOms7s%253D&md5=12d8dd359bec994b53488cf59ca2406c

        8c
        Synthesis, Structure Determination, and Hydrogen Sorption Studies of New Metal-Organic Frameworks Using Triazole and Naphthalenedicarboxylic Acid
        Park, Hyunsoo; Britten, James F.; Mueller, Ulrich; Lee, JeongYong; Li, Jing; Parise, John B.
        Chemistry of Materials (2007), 19 (6), 1302-1308CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        Two new metal-org. framework compds. were synthesized under solvothermal conditions using Zn2+ ion, 1,2,4-triazole (HTRZ), and 1,4- and 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acids (NDC): Zn4(TRZ)4(1,4-NDC)2·2DMF·2H2O (1) and Zn4(TRZ)4(2,6-NDC)2·2DMF·4H2O (2). Their crystal structures were characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Structure 1 crystallizes in the space group P21/n with a 13.609(2), b 27.181(5), c 13.617(3) Å, β 92.46(1)°, and Z = 4. Structure 2 crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Pna21 with a 30.978(6), b 12.620(3), c 13.339(3) Å, and Z = 4. Both structures are analogs of the previously reported Zn4(TRZ)4(1,4-BDC)2·16H2O where the layers of Zn-triazole moieties are pillared by arom. dicarboxylates to create 3-dimensional open frameworks. Nitrogen sorption studies revealed that these structures have Brunaer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of 362.1-584.1 m2/g. Hydrogen sorption expts. showed they can store 0.84-1.09% of H2 at 77 K and 1 atm. Although they do not contain large pores or surface areas, they possess the hydrogen sorption capacities comparable to those of highly porous metal-org. frameworks.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Design of Novel Three-Dimensional Coordination Polymers Based on Triangular Trinuclear Copper 1,2,4-Triazolate Units
        Zhai, Quan-Guo; Lu, Can-Zhong; Chen, Shu-Mei; Xu, Xin-Jiang; Yang, Wen-Bin
        Crystal Growth & Design (2006), 6 (6), 1393-1398CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        By controlling the molar ratios of Cu dichloride dihydrate and 1,2,4-triazole (trz), the authors generated novel three-dimensional coordination polymers constructed from μ3-oxo or μ3-Cl triangular Cu units, exhibiting six-connected porous self-penetrating net, graphite layer, and inorg.-org. hybrid network structures, resp. The prepn. and crystal structure of [Cu3(μ3-O)(μ3-trz)3]2[OH]2·15H2O (1), Cu[Cu3(μ3-O)(μ3-trz)3Cl3] (2) and [Cu2(μ3-trz)(μ3-Cl)2] (3) are reported.

        A novel 3D hybrid architecture based on (H2O)6 encircling Cu4I4-O-Cu4I4 cluster and hexanuclear Cu6(datrz)6 ring
        Zhai, Quan-Guo; Lu, Can-Zhong; Chen, Shu-Mei; Xu, Xin-Jiang; Yang, Wen-Bin
        Inorganic Chemistry Communications (2006), 9 (8), 819-822CODEN: ICCOFP; ISSN:1387-7003. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The reaction of ligand datrz (3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole) with CuI in 1:1 EtOH and H2O mixed solvent under solvothermal conditions gives a novel three-dimensional hybrid solid, [(H3O)2(H2O)4][{Cu6(datrz)6}{(Cu4I4)2O}] (1), which consists of unique six-connected dumbbell-like Cu4I4-O-Cu4I4 clusters and hexanuclear Cu6(datrz)6 rings. The chair-form H2O hexamer is firstly obsd. being interpenetrated by the inorg. cluster.

        Hydrothermal Synthesis and Structure of a Three-Dimensional Cobalt(II) Triazolate Magnet
        Ouellette, Wayne; Galan-Mascaros, Jose R.; Dunbar, Kim R.; Zubieta, Jon
        Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (5), 1909-1911CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The reaction of CoCl2·6H2O, 1,2,4-triazole, and H2O at 200° for 96 h yields purple rods of [Co2(trz)3Cl] (1; trz = 1,2,4-triazolate) in 90% yield. The structure of 1 consists of {Co(trz)3}nn- chains of CoII sites linked through tetrahedral sites of {CoN3Cl} geometry into a three-dimensional framework. The competing antiferromagnetic interactions of the octahedral and tetrahedral CoII centers result in weak ferromagnetic behavior below Tc = 9 K.

        13b
        Construction of Cd/Zn(II)-1,2,4-Triazolate Coordination Complexes via Changing Substituents and Anions
        Zhai, Quan-Guo; Wu, Xiao-Yuan; Chen, Shu-Mei; Lu, Can-Zhong; Yang, Wen-Bin
        Crystal Growth & Design (2006), 6 (9), 2126-2135CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Zero- to three-dimensional Cd/Zn(II)-1,2,4-triazole or -triazolate coordination complexes were obtained by changing the anions and the substituents on the triazole ring. Cd2(2-pytrz)2Cl4 (1) and Cd3(dpatrz)4Cl6 (2) (2-pytrz = 3,5-di(pyrid-2-yl)-1,2,4-triazole and dpatrz = 3,5-di(n-propyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole) have discrete binuclear and trinuclear structures, resp. Cd3(atrz)4Cl6 (3) and Cd(atrz)2(SCN)2 (4) (atrz = 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole) are polymeric 1-dimensional chains constructed from trinuclear Cd units and mononuclear cores. Cd(datrz)I (5), Zn(dmtrz)Cl (6), and Cd3(dmatrz)4(N3)6 (7) (datrz = 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazolate, dmtrz = 3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazolate, and dmatrz = 3,5-dimethyl-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole) all show two-dimensional layer structures. Complexes 5 and 6 are 2-dimensional grids based on binuclear clusters and present (4.82)metal(4.82)trz topol. Complex 7 is of 2-dimensional (4,4) topol. when trinuclear Cd units are regarded as four-connected nodes. For complexes 1-7, weak H-bonding contacts link the discrete polynuclear clusters, 1-dimensional chains, or 2-dimensional layers to form three-dimensional supramol. structures. Zn2(trz)3Cl (8) (trz = 1,2,4-triazolate) presents an interesting 3-dimensional network based on three nonequivalent nodes and has a (46861224)(861254)(42841236)3 topol. Complexes 1-8 all exhibit strong blue fluorescence emission bands in the solid state at ambient temp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xot1Chu7s%253D&md5=883a5cef9acd4130797940d344923e17
      14. 14
        (a) Ockwig, N. W.; Delgado-Friedrichs, O.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Acc. Chem. Res. 2005, 38, 176
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14a
        Reticular Chemistry: Occurrence and Taxonomy of Nets and Grammar for the Design of Frameworks
        Ockwig, Nathan W.; Delgado-Friedrichs, Olaf; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2005), 38 (3), 176-182CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        The structures of all 1127 three-periodic extended metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) reported in the Cambridge Structure Database were analyzed, and their underlying topol. was detd. It is remarkable that among the almost infinite no. of net topologies that are available for MOFs to adopt, only a handful of nets are actually obsd. The discovery of this inversion between expected and obsd. nets led the authors to deduce a system of classification taxonomy for interpreting and rationalizing known MOF structures, as well as those that will be made in future. The origin of this inversion is attributed to the different modes with which MOF synthesis was approached. Specifically, three levels of complexity are defined that embody rules grammar for the design of MOFs and other extended structures. This system accounts for the present proliferation of MOF structures of high symmetry nets, but more importantly, it provides the basis for designing a building block that codes for a specific structure and, indeed, only that structure.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXksFSgsg%253D%253D&md5=13530d98a4733672738db281372887ae
        (b) http://rcsr.anu.edu.au/home.
        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      15. 15
        Rosi, N. L.; Kim, J.; Eddaoudi, M.; Chen, B.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2005, 127, 1504
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        15
        Rod Packings and Metal-Organic Frameworks Constructed from Rod-Shaped Secondary Building Units
        Rosi, Nathaniel L.; Kim, Jaheon; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Chen, Banglin; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (5), 1504-1518CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The principal structure possibilities for packing infinite rod-shaped building blocks are described. Some basic nets derived from linking simple rods (helixes and ladders) are then enumerated. The authors demonstrate the usefulness of the concept of rod secondary building units in the design and synthesis of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs). Accordingly, the authors present the prepn., characterization, and crystal structures of 14 new MOFs (named MOF-69A-C and MOF-70-80) of 12 different structure types, belonging to rod packing motifs, and show how their structures are related to basic nets. The MOFs reported herein are of polytopic carboxylates and contain one of Zn, Pb, Co, Cd, Mn, or Tb. The inclusion properties of the most open members are presented as evidence that MOF structures with rod building blocks can indeed be designed to have permanent porosity and rigid architectures.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXjtFGmtg%253D%253D&md5=0ad22a135cba65fb519eae17258dc4c8
      16. 16
        (a) Soma, T.; Yuge, H.; Iwamoto, T. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 1994, 33, 1665
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (b) Duncan, P. C. M.; Goodgame, D. M. L.; Menzer, S.; Williams, D. J. Chem. Commun. 1996, 2127
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16b
        Formation of an infinite interpenetrating three-dimensional network by tris(N,N'-butylenebisimidazole)manganese (II) tetrafluoroborate
        Duncan, Patrick C. M.; Goodgame, David M. L.; Menzer, Stephan; Williams, David J.
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge) (1996), (18), 2127-2128CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The prepn. and crystal structure of [Mn(N,N'-butylenebis(imidazole))3](BF4)2 (I) and prepn. of its I- analog are reported. I comprises two equiv., mutually interpenetrating three-dimensional networks of 44-membered rings. Crystal data are reported in rhombohedral space group R‾3, R1 = 0.056.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28XmtFyjsrw%253D&md5=2207da2b6a90f60a7b1a16179229ae16
        (c) Siebel, E.; Fischer, R. D. Chem.—Eur. J. 1997, 3, 1987
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16c
        Polymeric [(Me3Sn)3Rh(SCN)6]: a novel "super-Prussian-blue" derivative containing the nonlinear -SCN-Sn-NCS- spacer
        Siebel, Eric; Fischer, R. Dieter
        Chemistry - A European Journal (1997), 3 (12), 1987-1991CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        The new coordination polymer [(Me3SnIV)3RhIII(SCN)6] = ∞3[Rh{μ-(SCNSnMe3NCS)}3] (5) is readily accessible by straightforward self-assembly of [Rh(SCN)6]3- and (dehydrated) {Me3Sn}aq+ ions. 5 Was characterized by x-ray crystallog. (rhombohedral, space group R3c, R1 = 0.0649). The architecture of 5 is strongly reminiscent of super-Prussian-blue systems reported earlier: there is a three-dimensional (3-D) framework involving {Rh8} pseudocubes as the basic building blocks, the Rh3+ ions being held apart by novel, nonlinear {SCN-SnMe3-NCS} spacers (d(Rh···Rh) = 1.27 nm). The complete lattice consists of two equiv. and independent, ideally interwoven 3-dimensional frameworks. Three homologs of 5 with slightly modified R3Sn units (R = Et, Pr and Bu) were prepd. as well, but display x-ray powder diffraction patterns notably different from that of 5.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXltV2jug%253D%253D&md5=48079f0c5a83eb5adaebf43c5dd4a397
        (d) Plater, M. J.; Foreman, M. R.; Skakle, M. S. Cryst. Eng. 2001, 4, 293
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (e) Abrahams, B. F.; Hoskins, B. F.; Robson, R.; Slizys, D. A. CrystEngComm 2002, 4, 478
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16e
        α-Polonium coordination networks constructed from bis(imidazole) ligands
        Abrahams, Brendan F.; Hoskins, Bernard F.; Robson, Richard; Slizys, Damian A.
        CrystEngComm (2002), 4 (), 478-482CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Two types of bis(imidazole) ligands, 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bix) and 1,4-bis(imidazolyl)-2-butyne (bib), were used to bridge octahedral metal centers and form simple cubic networks. Crystal structures of Cd(bix)3(ClO4)2, Cd(bix)3(NO3)2, Zn(bib)3(BF4)2 and Co(bib)3(NO3)2 reveal that all possess the α-Po topol. and are triply interpenetrating.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XmvFymsLk%253D&md5=41ccfb5969f0c2b01e01991c497b98b8
        (f) Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, J.; Rosi, N.; Vodak, D.; Wachter, J.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Science 2002, 295, 469
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16f
        Systematic design of pore size and functionality in isoreticular MOFs and their application in methane storage
        Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon; Rosi, Nathaniel; Vodak, David; Wachter, Joseph; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2002), 295 (5554), 469-472CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        A strategy based on reticulating metal ions and org. carboxylate links into extended networks has been advanced to a point that allowed the design of porous structures in which pore size and functionality could be varied systematically. Metal-org. framework (MOF-5), a prototype of a new class of porous materials and one that is constructed from octahedral Zn-O-C clusters and benzene links, was used to demonstrate that its three-dimensional porous system can be functionalized with the org. groups -Br, -NH2, -OC3H7, -OC5H11, -C2H4, and -C4H4 and that its pore size can be expanded with the long mol. struts biphenyl, tetrahydropyrene, pyrene, and terphenyl. We synthesized an isoreticular series (one that has the same framework topol.) of 16 highly cryst. materials whose open space represented up to 91.1% of the crystal vol., as well as homogeneous periodic pores that can be incrementally varied from 3.8 to 28.8 Å. One member of this series exhibited a high capacity for methane storage (240 cm3 at std. temp.), and others the lowest densities (0.41 to 0.21 g/cm3) for a cryst. material at room temp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlyrtLjP&md5=d218d4040887f5fb390a733ee156d27b
        (g) Jensen, P.; Batten, S. R.; Moubaraki, B.; Murray, K. S. Dalton Trans. 2002, 3712
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16g
        Syntheses, crystal structures, and magnetic properties of first row transition metal coordination polymers containing dicyanamide and 4,4'-bipyridine
        Jensen, Paul; Batten, Stuart R.; Moubaraki, Boujemaa; Murray, Keith S.
        Journal of the Chemical Society, Dalton Transactions (2002), (19), 3712-3722CODEN: JCSDAA; ISSN:1472-7773. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The complexes M(dca)2(bipy) (M = Fe 1, Co 2, Ni 3; dca = dicyanamide, N(CN)2-; bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine) and M(dca)2(bipy)(H2O)·0.5MeOH (M = Mn 4, Fe 5, Co 6), were synthesized and characterized by single crystal and powder x-ray diffraction. Compds. 1-3 contain two interpenetrating 3-dimensional α-Po related networks. Bidentate dca ligands bridge the octahedral metal atoms to form square-grid like M(dca)2 sheets, with the bipyridine ligands linking these sheets together to form the α-Po-like 3-dimensional networks. The large amt. of space within a single 3-dimensional network allows the interpenetration of the 2nd 3-dimensional network. Compds. 4-6 contain 1-dimensional tubes' packing together in a parallel interdigitated fashion. H2O ligands coordinated to the octahedral metal ions and intercalated MeOH mols. occupy the inside of the M(dca)2 tubes while protruding monodentate bipyridine ligands participate in both π-stacking and H bonding interactions between adjacent tubes. Co(dca)2(bipy)·0.5H2O·0.5MeOH 7 and Cu(dca)2(bipy)·H2O 8 consist of inclined interpenetrating 2-dimensional sheets of M(dca)2(bipy), while Cu(dca)2(bipy)·MeOH 9 and Cu(dca)2(bipy)·2H2O 10 contain 2-dimensional zigzag sheets of Cu(dca)2(bipy) with parallel packing. Fe(dca)2(bipy)(H2O)2·(bipy) 11 contains 1-dimensional chains of Fe(bipy) with H bonding extending the topol. to that of two 3-dimensional interpenetrating α-Po related networks. Compds. 7 and 11 contain octahedral metal ions, while 8 and 9 have five-coordinate Cu atoms. Variable temp. magnetic susceptibility studies (2-300 K; H = 1 T) showed that these framework compds. generally display very weak antiferromagnetic coupling because of the long bipy and μ1,5 bridging pathways. Consequently no long-range magnetic order occurs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XnsVKrsLg%253D&md5=53263c9e891476afd059fb892b362c95
        (h) Niel, V.; Munoz, M. C.; Gaspar, A. B.; Galet, A.; Levchenko, G.; Real, J. A. Chem.—Eur. J. 2002, 8, 2446
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16h
        Thermal-, pressure-, and light-induced spin transition in novel cyanide-bridged FeII-AgI bimetallic compounds with three-dimensional interpenetrating double structures {FeIILx[Ag(CN)2]2}·G
        Niel, Virginie; Munoz, M. Carmen; Gaspar, Ana B.; Galet, Ana; Levchenko, Georg; Real, Jose Antonio
        Chemistry--A European Journal (2002), 8 (11), 2446-2453CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        Low-spin, high-spin and spin-transition behaviors were obsd. for the doubly interpenetrating three-dimensional bimetallic compds. {FeII(pz)[Ag(CN)2]2}·pz (pz = pyrazine), {FeII(4,4'-bipy)2[Ag(CN)2]2} (4,4'-bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine), and {FeII(bpe)2[Ag(CN)2]2} (bpe = bispyridylethylene), resp. The single crystals of the bpe deriv. undergo a spin transition with a large hysteresis loop at ∼95 K. After several warming and cooling cycles, the single crystals become a microcryst. powder with 50% spin transition. Influence of pressure- as well as light-induced excited spin-state trapping (LIESST) on the thermal 50% spin transition of the microcryst. sample also was studied. Thermal spin-transition behavior also was induced at pressures >1 bar for the 4,4'-bipy deriv. Both the 4,4'-bipy and bpe derivs. show strong pressure dependence of the spin state at 300 K.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XksFWgs7Y%253D&md5=27c45838cfefc8a4a6ce9268c0a2b7d6
        (i) Lu, W. J.; Zhang, L. P.; Song, H. B.; Wang, Q. M.; Mak, T. C. W. New J. Chem. 2002, 26, 775
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16i
        Novel lanthanide(III) coordination networks based on 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane-N,N'-dioxide and trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene-N,N'-dioxide
        Lu, Wen-Jie; Zhang, Lin-Ping; Song, Hai-Bin; Wang, Quan-Ming; Mak, Thomas C. W.
        New Journal of Chemistry (2002), 26 (6), 775-781CODEN: NJCHE5; ISSN:1144-0546. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The new ligand 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane-N,N'-dioxide (L) was used to generate five lanthanide(III) coordination networks of three structural types: (i) the isomorphous pair {[Ln(L)3]·(ClO4)3·(H2O)}∞ (Ln = Er, 1; Yb, 2) comprises two interpenetrating α-Po nets in which each lanthanide(III) ion is in a rare homoleptic distorted octahedral coordination environment; (ii) an unprecedented mat-like pattern of three interwoven (6,3) nets is found in isomorphous {[Ln(NO3)3(L)1.5]·H2O}∞ (Ln = Er, 3; Yb, 4); (iii) {[La(NO3)3(L) (MeOH)]· MeOH·CH2Cl2}∞, 5, is built of an offset stacking of distorted square grids. [Er(L')0.5(H2O)3(C2O4)](ClO4)·L'·6H2O·(dioxane)0.5 (L' = trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene-N,N'-dioxide), 6, is composed of (6,3) nets in which the Er(III) ions are bridged by both L' ligands and oxalate ions. The crystal structures of the 6 lanthanide complexes were detd.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xkt1Oms7c%253D&md5=5b0f7c4498909292cfd89cc45193ca2c
        (j) Yang, S. Y.; Long, L. S.; Jiang, Y. B.; Huang, R. B.; Zheng, L. S. Chem. Mater. 2002, 14, 3229
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16j
        An Exceptionally Stable Metal-Organic Framework Constructed from the Zn8(SiO4) Core
        Yang, S. Y.; Long, L. S.; Jiang, Y. B.; Huang, R. B.; Zheng, L. S.
        Chemistry of Materials (2002), 14 (8), 3229-3231CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        The hydrothermal synthesis, crystal structure, TGA and spectral properties of a metal-org. framework complex, [Zn8(SiO4)(C8H4O6)6]n (1, C8H4O6 = terephthalate dianion), are reported. 1 Contains an infinite interpenetrating three-dimensional framework with a Zn8(SiO4) distorted cubane-like core as a building unit. Two zinc atoms at each edge of the core are capped by a carboxylate group of terephthalate to form a 6-connected cluster Zn8(SiO4)(C8H4O6)12. TGA shows that 1 has exceptional thermal and chem. stability. In the solid state 1 exhibits strong fluorescence and weak phosphorescence, suggesting it may be a good candidate for diode devices.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XltlWkur0%253D&md5=2d29bfb5cb627d185d8f63de4a68d64e
        (k) Abrahams, B. F.; Batten, S. R.; Hoskins, B. F.; Robson, R. Inorg. Chem. 2003, 42, 2654
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16k
        AgC(CN)3-Based Coordination Polymers
        Abrahams, Brendan F.; Batten, Stuart R.; Hoskins, Bernard F.; Robson, Richard
        Inorganic Chemistry (2003), 42 (8), 2654-2664CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Reaction of Ag(tcm), tcm = tricyanomethanide, C(CN)3-, with a range of terminal and bridging ligands gave new coordination polymers, whose structures were detd. by x-ray crystallog. Recrystn. of Ag(tcm) from acetonitrile generates Ag(tcm)(MeCN), which is composed of corrugated (6,3) sheets displaying 2-fold 2-dimensional → 2-dimensional parallel interpenetration and is topol. identical to the parent Ag(tcm) structure. Ag(tcm)(L) species, L = 1,4-diazobicyclo[2.2.2]octane (dabco) or 4,4'-bipyridine (bipy), contain two interpenetrating 3-dimensional networks composed of 3-connecting (tcm) and 5-connecting (Ag) centers. The structure of Ag(tcm)(bpe), bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene, contains 1-dimensional ladderlike polymers connected by weak Ag-tcm interactions into two interpenetrating 3-dimensional nets. Ag(tcm)(Mepyz)3/2, Mepyz = methylpyrazine, also contains 1-dimensional ladders, while Ag(tcm)(Me4pyz)1/2, Me4pyz = tetramethylpyrazine, contains 2-dimensional sheets composed of Ag(tcm) 1-dimensional tubes linked by bridging Me4pyz ligands. Ag(tcm)(hmt), hmt = hexamethylenetetramine, has a 3-dimensional network structure in which the hmt ligands are 3-connecting, the tcm anions are 2-connecting, and the silver atoms are 5-connecting. The topol. is the same as displayed by Ag(tcm)(L), L = dabco or bipy.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXitFGmsr0%253D&md5=7aeb2fbb99fabb370a035a4dfa94e6fc

        Batten, S. R. CrystEngComm 2001, 3, 67
        [Crossref], Google Scholar

      18. 18
        Hun, H.; Kim, D.; Dybtsev, D. N.; Kim, K. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed., 2004, 43, 971
        [Crossref], [PubMed], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      19. 19
        Verelst, M.; Sommier, L.; Lecante, P.; Mosset, A.; Kahn, O. Chem. Mater. 1998, 10, 980
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19
        Structural Study by Wide-Angle X-ray Scattering of the Spin Transition Molecular Materials [Fe(Htrz)2(trz)](BF4) and [Fe(NH2trz)3](NO3)2 (Htrz = 1,2,4-4H-triazole, trz = 1,2,4-triazolato)
        Verelst, Marc; Sommier, Line; Lecante, Pierre; Mosset, Alain; Kahn, Olivier
        Chemistry of Materials (1998), 10 (4), 980-985CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        A precise structural study by wide-angle x-ray scattering (WAXS) was carried out on two spin transition materials: [Fe(Htrz)2(trz)](BF4) (1) and [Fe(NH2trz)3](NO3)2 (2), with Htrz = 1,2,4-4H-triazole, trz = 1,2,4-triazolato, and NH2trz = 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole, both at room temp. in the low-spin state (LS) and at higher temp. in the high-spin state (HS). These compds. exhibit cooperative spin transitions between LS and HS state above room temp. with a large thermal hysteresis and a pronounced thermochromic effect. Both compds. have a polymeric chain structure where each Fe2+ metal ion is triply bridged to their neighbors through N atoms of the triazole or triazolato groups. In the LS state the polymeric chain is linear, whereas at higher temp., in the HS state, the magnetic transition causes an elongation and a deformation of the chain. The chain loses its linear character. The authors explain this behavior by a rhombic-type distortion of the Fe octahedral environment assocd. with the spin transition. Compd. 1 presents an important interchain order in the LS state, probably due to a H-bond network connecting together linear chains through N-H···BF4···H-N linkages, where the N atoms occupy the 4-position of the triazole ligands. When the spin transition occurs, the interchain long-range order vanishes. For compd. 2 each polymeric chain seems to be independent from its neighbors.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXitVyqtLc%253D&md5=f4ff2998efd0f8518f48d1791bb7a54e
      20. 20
        Zheng, S. L.; Chen, X. M. Aust. J. Chem. 2004, 57, 703
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        20
        Recent Advances in Luminescent Monomeric, Multinuclear, and Polymeric Zn(II) and Cd(II) Coordination Complexes
        Zheng, Shao-Liang; Chen, Xiao-Ming
        Australian Journal of Chemistry (2004), 57 (8), 703-712CODEN: AJCHAS; ISSN:0004-9425. (CSIRO Publishing)
        A review. This article briefly summarizes recent progress on the luminescence studies of monomeric, multinuclear, and polymeric Zn(II)/Cd(II) coordination complexes, involving spectroscopic, photophys., and photochem. studies, as well as mol. and electronic structural investigations, focusing mainly on the interplaying factors that govern the luminescent origin of the lowest-lying emissive states. Current results show that, for Zn(II)/Cd(II) coordination complexes in general, the nature of the metal centers and ligands and the rigid metal-oxy (or -hydroxy) clusters are factors governing their luminescent origin of the lowest-lying emissive states; different types of ligands and coordination structures may result in different emission mechanisms.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXmsFSksr8%253D&md5=b6e661179fcfafc67a60e211dc193ea0
